_description.iso_639_3_eng:
The *term* is the *base element* of the *data dictionary*. *All elements* of the *dictionary* are *terms* that, depending on which sections they feature, fill the role of *descriptors*, *types*, *structures* and *other* constructs that comprise the data dictionary.

A term features *six sections*, or *structures*, that determine its *function*:

- [Identification section](_code.md). This section contains all the necessary information to *identify* terms, both in the *data dictionary* and when *sharing terms* in *other contexts*. All terms *require* this section.
- [Information section](_info.md). This section contains a set of properties that are used to *define* and *describe terms* to *human users*. All terms *require* this section.
- [Categories section](_tags.md). This section groups a set of *controlled vocabulary properties* that define *categories*, *groups* and *tags* associated with the term. This section is *optional*.
- [Data section](_data.md). This section defines what *shape*, *type* and *constraints* apply to *data* belonging to the *current term*. This section is *required* for all *terms* that *represent descriptors* or *variables*, *terms* that *do not represent descriptors* must *omit* this section.
- [Structure section](_struct.md). This section defines and object structure data type. It contains the necessary properties to indicate which properties the object is allowed, required or forbidden to feature. All terms that represent an *object data type* must include this section, unless no constraints are required. Terms that feature this section can be used as *structure data types*.
- [Private section](_private.md). This section can be used to add *custom data* to the term, the section has *no constraints*, so you can *store* here *anything you need*. The contents of this section are considered *private*, so *no validation* will be performed. This section is *optional*.

A term can have *more* than *one* role, depending on *which sections* it features. Terms that represent *controlled vocabulary elements* are organised in *hierarchical structures* that are implemented by directional predicate *graphs*.

It is assumed by default that *all terms reside in the same collection*. The unique identifier, `_key`, of the term is, by convention, set to the term's [global identifier](_gid.md) which *uniquely identifies* a term in the *whole dictionary*. *All term references* are required to hold the term's `_key` value.

The *identification section* of a *term* contains all the *codes* that *identify* the *term* in the *database* and in *other contexts*. A term is uniquely identified by its [global identifier](_gid.md), which is generated by concatenating the [namespace](_nid.md) and the [local identifier](_lid.md).

The section features the following properties:

- [Namespace](_nid.md). This is a *code* that *represents* the *namespace* of the term. Namespaces are used to *group* a set of *local identifiers* under a *common category*, allowing the reuse of local identifiers in different contexts. The *namespace* is the *global identifier* of the *term* that represents the namespace.
- [Local identifier](_lid.md). This is the *code* that *uniquely identifies* the term *within* its *namespace*. This property is *required* and cannot be an empty string.
- [Global identifier](_gid.md). This is the *unique identifier* of the term *among all namespaces*. The code is the *concatenation* of the *namespace* and the *local identifier* separated by an *underscore* (`_`) token. This property is *computed* and *required*.
- [Uniform Resource Name](_urn.md). Terms that represent items having a [Uniform Resource Name (URN)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Name) can set the URN in this property. Only *one* URN should be associated to a term.
- [Uniform Resource Locator](_url.md). Terms that have an entry on the internet or in an ontology can set the address in this property. Only *one* [URL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/URL) should be associated to a term.
- [All identifiers](_aid.md). This is the list of all known *local* identifiers associated with the *term*. This property is used to *select* a *term* that has *several* local *identifier versions*. The current *local identifier* must be *included* in this list.
- [Provider identifiers](_pid.md). This list should include *all identifiers* that *data providers* use when *referencing* the *term*. This can be useful when we receive data without metadata.
- [Regular expression](regexp.md). This property may contain a *regular expression* that constrains the code of the *local identifier*.

*All terms require this section*.

_examples.iso_639_3_eng:
The following structure represents the *code section* of the term that references the International Standards Organisation (ISO). The term is generally used as a namespace for standard controlled vocabulary elements.

The term has no *namespace*, `_nid`, so it can be used as a top level namespace. Its *global identifier*, `_gid`, takes the same value as its *local identifier*, `_lid`. It features the *local identifier* in the list of *all identifiers*, `_aid`. The term does not feature a *uniform resource name*, `_urn`, but it features a default *uniform resource locator*, `_url`.

```json
{
	"_key": "iso",
	"_code": {
		"_lid": "iso",
		"_gid": "iso",
		"_url": "https://www.iso.org/home.html",
		"_aid": ["iso"]
	}
}

```

Next we have the *code section* of the term that references the dictionary [term structure](_term.md). The term belongs to the dictionary default namespace.

The section features a *namespace*, `_nid`, with an *empty string*: this is only allowed for *default dictionary namespace* entries and *not* for *user defined* terms. Since there is an empty namespace the *global identifier*, `_gid`, begins with the separator token (`_`).

```json
{
	"_key": "_term",
	"_code": {
		"_nid": "",
		"_lid": "term",
		"_gid": "_term",
		"_aid": ["term"]
	}
}

```

In the following example we show the *code section* of the *term* that *represents* the [ISO 3166 country codes](https://www.iso.org/iso-3166-country-codes.html) *part 1* standards code for the country *Italy*.

The *namespace*, `_nid`, is already a combination of three terms: the [ISO](iso.md) namespace (`iso`), the [ISO 3166 country codes](iso_3166.md) namespace (`iso_3166`) and the [ISO 3166 country codes part 1](iso_3166_1.md) namespace, (`iso_3166_1`). The *local identifier*, `_lid`, is set to the [alpha-3](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-3) code version, `ITA`. Besides the three character code, the list of *all identifiers*, `_aid`, also contains the [alpha-2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-2), `IT`, and [numeric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_numeric), `380`, versions of the code, this allows locating the *unique identifier*, `_key`, of *Italy* in the dictionary using any version of the standard.

Finally, the section features the regular expression, `regexp`, that governs the *local identifier*, `_lid`: it must be an upper-case 3-character code: this can be useful to ensure we are receiving correct data.

```json
{
	"_key": "iso_3166_1_ITA",
	"_code": {
		"_nid": "iso_3166_1",
		"_lid": "ITA",
		"_gid": "iso_3166_1_ITA",
		"_aid": ["IT", "ITA", "380"],
		"regexp": "[A-Z]{3}"
	}
}

```

In the following example we show the *code section* of a *term* that *represents* the *average elevation* descriptor.

The namespace, `_nid`, is a combination of two terms: the *environment*, `env`, and the *elevation*, `elevation`, terms joined together to group *all elevation related terms*: this can be handy when we want to differentiate *average*, *standard deviation*, *variance*, etc. Here we have a *uniform resource name*, `_urn`, that references the [wikidata ontology](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata:Main_Page). We also feature a *uniform resource locator*, `_url`, that points to the wikidata ontology [web entry](https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P2044). The *all identifiers*, `_aid`, lists the current *local identifier* value. Finally, the section features two entries in the *provider identifiers* list, `_pid`, which correspond to two variable names that our data providers use to reference average elevation.

```json
{
	"_key": "env_elevation_avg",
	"_code": {
		"_nid": "env_elevation",
		"_lid": "avg",
		"_gid": "env_elevation_avg",
		"_urn": "wikidata:P2044",
		"_url": "https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Property:P2044",
		"_aid": ["avg"],
		"_pid": ["AvElevation", "average_elevation"]
	}
}
```

_description.iso_639_3_eng:
The *information section* serves the purpose of providing *information* to users regarding the term. While the [identification section](_code.md) is mostly used to identify specific terms. the *information section* must provide all the necessary material to users regarding *what* the term represents and *how* it can be *used*.

This section features a series of properties that provide information targeting *experts*, *general users* and the *public* at large:

- [Name](_name.md). The *name* is a bridge between the [identification section](_code.md) and this section, it should reflect the term's *given name*. It is a *single string*, so it should be in the original language, if relevant.
- [Title](_title.md). The *title* or *label* of the term should provide as much information as possible, taking into consideration the *current context*. It would typically be the label used in a form, or the header of a table. The property is structured as a key/value object in which the key is the *language code* and the value is the *title* in *plain text*. This property is *required*.
- [Definition](_definition.md). This property should provide a *complete description* of the term, *understandable* by people *familiar* with the *subject matter*. The text should be both *concise*, but also, as much as possible, *complete*, so that *subject experts* may *fully understand* what the term is about. The property is structured as a key/value object in which the key is the *language code* and the value is the *definition* in *plain text*. This property is *strongly recommended*, *unless* if it might become *redundant* with the *title*.
- [Description](_description.md). This property should contain all the necessary *information* that can be of use to people *not familiar* with the *subject matter*, and *including* everything that is *assumed* in the *definition*. In particular, this field should provide information on *why* the *term* is *important*, on *how* to *use* it and on *what* are the *methods* to obtain eventual data related to the term. Once somebody has read this field, he/she should be able to take advantage of the term and use it at its best. This property is structured as a key/value structure in which the key is the *language code* and the value is the *description* in [Markdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown) markup language, this makes it possible to add references to internet material that can be of value. This property is *strongly recommended*, *except* if it might become *redundant* with the *definition*.
- [Examples](_examples.md). This property should contain *usage examples* of the *term*. This field makes sense in situations where the term is a descriptor that must be filled using a special protocol, or in cases where it can be used in different ways. The field is *indexed* by *language* and the text is encoded in [Markdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markdown) markup language. This field is *optional*.

This section should be used in the *user interface* whenever displaying *data reports*, or when generating data *input forms*.

_examples.iso_639_3_eng:
The following structure represents the *information section* of the term that represents the descriptor of the *elevation variable*. The term defines variables that measure location height above sea level in meters.

The *title*, `_title`, property contains a label that can be used where the context is clear, such as in the label of a data input form or in the header of a data column. The *definition*, `_definition`, can provide *more information* to users that have a *good understanding* of the *subject matter*, it could be a popup displayed when hovering over the label in the user interface. The *description*, `_description`, should provide *enough information* to users *not familiar* with the *subject matter*, it contains *links* to *resources* in the *internet* that can provide *further knowledge* on the matter. *Examples*, `_examples`, provides two value examples, it mainly shows elevation *range* on Earth and indicates that you may have *negative* values.

It is important to note that title and definition are plain text elements, while description and examples are rich text elements. All properties are expressed in several languages.

```json
{
	"_info": {
		"_title": {
			"iso_639_3_eng": "Elevation",
			"iso_639_3_ita": "Altitudine",
			...
		},
		"_definition": {
			"iso_639_3_eng": "Height above sea level in meters.",
			"iso_639_3_ita": "Distanza verticale di un oggetto dal livello del mare in metri."
			...
		},
		"_description": {
			"iso_639_3_eng": "The *elevation* of a [geographic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic) [location](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Location_(geography)) is its [height](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Height) above or below a fixed reference point, most commonly a reference [geoid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoid), a [mathematical model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_model) of the [Earth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth)'s [sea level](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_level) as an [equipotential](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equipotential)[gravitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitation) [surface](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equipotential_surface) (see [Geodetic datum § Vertical datum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geodetic_datum#Vertical_datum)).

Elevation is not to be confused with the distance from the center of the Earth. Due to the [equatorial bulge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equatorial_bulge), the summits of [Mount Everest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Everest) and [Chimborazo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chimborazo_(volcano)) have, respectively, the largest elevation and the largest [geocentric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ECEF) distance.

Source [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elevation).",
			"iso_639_3_ita": "L'*altitudine* è la [distanza verticale](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distanza_euclidea) di un oggetto dal [livello del mare](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Livello_del_mare), ossia l'altezza sul livello del mare, o altezza assoluta, una delle tre [coordinate geografiche](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coordinate_geografiche) terrestri assieme alla [latitudine](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latitudine) e alla [longitudine](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitudine).

Il termine generico altezza si riferisce invece all'altezza relativa, ovvero la distanza di un oggetto da un livello di riferimento arbitrario ossia la differenza tra le altitudini di due diversi luoghi, ad esempio tra la vetta di una montagna e il fondovalle o tra un aeromobile e il terreno sottostante.

Fonte [Wikipedia](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altitudine)."
			...
		},
		"_examples": {
			"iso_639_3_eng": "`8848.86` is the elevation in meters of [Mount Everest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Everest).

`-430.5` is the lowest elevation of the [Dead Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dead_Sea) lake's surface as of 2019.",
			"iso_639_3_ita": "`8848.86` è l'altitudine in metri del [Monte Everest](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everest).

`-430.5` l'altitudine del [Mar Morto](https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mar_Morto) registrata nel 2019."
			...
		}
	}
}

```

Next we have the *code section* of the term that represents the country *Italy*.

The section features the *name*, `_name`, property that records the *original name* for Italy, It features the *title*, `_title`, in several languages with the *country short name* and it features the *definition*, `_definition`, with the *official name* in several languages.

This is an example of a controlled vocabulary elementthat features only the essential information.

```json
{
	"_info": {
		"_name": "Italia",
		"_title": {
			"iso_639_3_eng": "Italy",
			"iso_639_3_afr": "Italië",
			"iso_639_3_amh": "ጣሑ።ን",
			"iso_639_3_ara": "إيطاليا",
			"iso_639_3_asm": "ইটালি",
			"iso_639_3_aze": "İtaliya",
			"iso_639_3_bel": "Італія",
			"iso_639_3_bul": "Италия",
			"iso_639_3_ben": "ইটালি",
			...
		},
		"_definition": {
			"iso_639_3_eng": "Italian Republic",
			"iso_639_3_afr": "Italiaanse Republiek",
			"iso_639_3_amh": "ፘመጢጘለኢፄ ጐፔሱጢ ሱፐብሑጤ",
			"iso_639_3_ara": "الجمهوريّة الإيطاليّة",
			"iso_639_3_asm": "ইটালিয়ান প্ৰজান্ত্ৰ",
			"iso_639_3_aze": "İtaliya",
			"iso_639_3_bel": "Італьянская Рэспубліка",
			"iso_639_3_bul": "Италианска република",
			"iso_639_3_ben": "ইটালিয়ান প্রজান্ত্র",
			...
		}
	}
}
```

_description.iso_639_3_eng:
The *categories section* of a *term* is used to group all *categorical properties* in a *single section*. These categorical properties should provide both *information* on the *nature* of the *term*, as well as providing *keywords* that can be used to *search* the *dictionary*:

- [Class](class.md) (`class`): the *class* of a term represents the *term's* *nature* and *function*, whether it is an *identifier*, a *quantitative* value or a *categorical* value. The field is an *array* of *controlled vocabulary elements*, so more than one category may apply. This category is *required*, at least to indicate whether descriptors hold *quantitative* values or not.
- [Domain](domain.md) (`domain`): the *domain* of a term should indicate whether the *term* is *environmental*, *economic*, *genetic*, *phenotipic*, etc. It should indicate to what *domains* the *term belongs*. This is also a *list* of *controlled vocabulary elements*, so a *term* may have *several domains*. This field should be filled *if relevant*.
- [Tags](tag.md) (`tag`): this property is a *list* of *controlled vocabulary elements* that indicate what *usage* the term may have. For instance, if the term is a descriptor that is used to illustrate the *vulnerability* of a population you would create the vulnerability tag and assign it. This property should be managed by the different teams that use it.
- [Keywords](keyword.md) (`keyword`): this property contains a *list of keywords* associated with the *term*. These keywords are *strings* and not controlled vocabularies, as with the other properties of this section, so you are free to use your own definitions. This is a *recommended* property in all cases.

The controlled vocabularies associated with these properties can be enriched in time with specialised enumerations that apply to specific areas of interest, this will allow *different teams* to *collaborate* *without disrupting* each other's *domains*.

The *data section* of a term *defines* the *type* and *constraints* of the *data* that the *term* should *contain*. All terms that represent a *data variable* or *descriptor* must feature this section. Here we find all the necessary information needed to *validate* data.

This object requires exactly *one* of the following properties:

- [Scalar data container](term_scalar.md): This property contains the *data type* definitions and *constraints* for *scalar data values*. A *scalar value* is a *single primitive* value or *object*.
- [Array data container](term_array.md): This property contains the *data type* definitions and *constraints* for *array data values*, which represent a *list* of *scalar values* of the *same type* that *may* include *duplicate values*.
- [Set data container](term_set.md): This property contains the *data type* definitions and *constraints* for *set data values*, which represent a *list* of *scalar values*, except objects, of the *same type* whose values must be *unique*.
- [Key/value dictionary data container](term_dict.md): This property contains the *key* and *value* definitions and *constraints* for *key/value dictionary values*. Keys must be *strings*, values can be of *any type*.

You can set this property to an *empty object*, in that case it means that there are *no constraints* for the current *descriptor values*.

This information is used to allow *data validation* and meaningful *data presentation*.

The *structure section* of a term contains the constraints that define an object data type. When a term *features* this *section* it become a *structure data type* that can be associated with *descriptor terms* of [object type](_type_object.md).

_definition.iso_639_3_eng: User defined and managed data section.

_description.iso_639_3_eng: The *user section* of a term can be used to store *custom data*. If you need to add *custom properties* to *terms*, use *this section*.
